author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AFTER nine years in Seattle, Mark Marvel was more than ready to come home to New York. Seattle was too homogeneous, too provincial and too rainy for his taste, he said. The longer he lived there, the more he craved New York. He hoped to return at some point, or at least to become fully bicoastal. After Mr. Marvel, 42, finished at Columbia
title: THE HUNT; Jumping at the Chance to Return to New York

body: It was just that kind of Sunday made for a couple of young brothers and their father, all wound up for winter. By the time the Buechner boys -- Dylan, 3, and Conor, 5 -- and their father, Terry, 36, had dug out their snow gear and arrived at Hillside Park in the Dumbo area of Brooklyn yesterday morning, there was just enough fresh snow on the
title: Snow in New York, Not Big, but Early

body: The Gowanus Canal often stinks and is almost always spotted with slicks of oil. The streets alongside it are practically deserted, the silence broken by the rumble of concrete mixers and oil tankers or the screech of buzz saws. Graffiti abounds, and no one would use the word harmonious for the landscape, where ramshackle wood-frame and brick row
title: From Open Sewer to Open for Gentrification; Many Gowanus Residents Want Its Collar to Remain Blue

author: Tim and Nina Zagat are the publishers of the Zagat Survey guides.
body: AT cocktail parties, family dinners, ballgames, even charity events, conversations across New York City invariably turn to two things: the staggering price of real estate and the latest new restaurant. But they're not separate issues. They are as intertwined as the cheese and crackers or vodka and vermouth that fuel the discussion. Fact is, if you
title: There Goes the Neighborhood

body: WE owe the existence of Brooklyn to the urban developers of more than a century ago. Since that time, the borough's open land has disappeared. That's how it goes in cities the world over; only a dead city never changes. But just as we'll always have developers, community activists and environmentalists will invariably seek to check their greed and
title: The Project That Ate Brooklyn

body: WHEN developers opened new buildings for sale in New York a year ago, brokers jostled for appointments, buyers camped out before open houses and people made decisions to part with thousands of dollars in a matter of minutes. One sales agent famously sold five luxury condos from the back seat of her BMW in a day. The frenzy has died down, but the
title: For Choicest Apartments, Many More Choices

body: TWO well-established retailers are opening stores in Midtown, providing nearby workers with new places to indulge in lunch-hour shopping. Abercrombie & Fitch, the clothing chain for teenagers, opened a four-level store (its largest in the world, below) at 720 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 306-0936. (Last week, Ruehl, Abercrombie's line for
title: OPEN FOR BUSINESS; Manhattan And Brooklyn

body: For Fernando Ferrer, there may be two New Yorks, as he is fond of saying. But there are also two campaigns. In one, which plays out in the polls, among political leaders and on the Sunday morning news programs, Mr. Ferrer's effort is on life support, incapable of rousing itself and headed for an undignified death. But in the other, a kind of shadow
title: THE 2005 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER; The 2 Ferrers: A Plodder in the Polls, a Celebrity on the Street

body: Young Arts Patrons TUESDAY -- A cocktail party and dance for young patrons of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, in the Allen Room on the fifth floor of the Time Warner Center, will aid audience development programs. Drinks, hors d'oeuvres and dancing to the music of deejay D-Nice begin at 8. Tickets, $125, from (212)875-5764, or $175 at the
title: BENEFITS

body: TO anyone tracing the ups and downs of Gap's fortunes over the last decade, it is striking how often the periodic sales dips have bounced like a Ping-Pong ball, attributed first to ''too much fashion,'' then to ''too many basics.'' The company's latest difficulty in selling collections that emphasized style over khakis led to the sudden replacement
title: Front Row; Gap Mounts a Safari And Bags Some Basics

body: The resurgence of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Williamsburg is well documented. But what is not as widely known is how well the downtown business district is doing, despite a still somewhat dog-eared appearance. What is more, the area is on the verge of a major transformation. In the borough's six million square feet of Class A office
title: SQUARE FEET; Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn

body: It can be helpful to approach a dance festival as if you were entering a thrift store: you have to sift through a lot of material, with no guarantee of finding something suitable. Jewels may abound, but they may also be overlooked out of sheer exhaustion. Friday night's program at the fifth annual Dumbo Dance Festival, directed by Young Soon Kim,
title: DANCE REVIEW; Daring an Audience to Choose Among a Potpourri of Spasms

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: Today is the finale of the annual Dumbo Art Under the Bridge Festival. There is not a huge number of restaurants in that Brooklyn neighborhood and its environs, but those that exist are varied. BUBBY'S (718) 222-0666; 1 Main Street (Water Street); $$; Article: 10/8/03. Long a family-friendly fixture in TriBeCa, Bubby's opened this branch in Dumbo
title: GOOD EATING/DUMBO; Under the Bridge

body: Perfect Privacy $1,350,000 NEW JERSEY: 150 Goodale Road, Andover A five-year-old, one-level contemporary home set on a secluded 10.5-acre lot bordered on two sides by a state park. There are woodsy views, and no need for curtains. A bridge hallway over a small ravine connects the family room and great room. The house has four bedrooms,
title: ON THE MARKET

body: Organizing a multiday dance festival is a hefty undertaking. But why stop at one? The tireless Young Soon Kim, artistic director of the White Wave arts center in Brooklyn, is doubling the festival pleasure this year. Starting this evening with the fifth annual Dumbo Dance Festival and continuing through Oct. 23 at the first International Dumbo
title: THE LISTINGS | OCT. 14-OCT. 20; DUMBO DANCE FESTIVAL AND INTERNATIONAL DUMBO DANCE FESTIVAL

body: THE chef Matthew Kenney has left Pure Food and Wine, the raw food restaurant on Irving Place that he opened last year. Now the restaurant's owner and manager are angrily accusing him of luring away employees for his new projects. Jeffrey Chodorow, who owns the restaurant, said he sued Mr. Kenney yesterday, accusing him of breach of contract and of
title: Owner and Manager In Dispute With Chef

body: FOR years, the artist Jennifer Dalton and her cherub-faced husband, Wellington Fan, had heard stories about Williamsburg being a toxic neighborhood, with houses built on sludge and lofts carved out of tainted factories. But they dismissed contamination fears as the price of living in New York. They were committed urbanites and saw no reason to
title: HABITATS/Williamsburg; Worry Triumphs Over Fear

body: Caroline Jane Prugh and Paige van den Burg celebrated their union last evening in the Great Meadow of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Mary L. Foulke, an Episcopal priest, led the commitment ceremony. Ms. Prugh, 31, is a general management associate at Stuart Thompson Productions, where she has worked on the plays ''Art,'' ''Proof,'' ''Take Me
title: Caroline Prugh, Paige van den Burg

body: SOME people got grumpy last year about City Center's sampler series Fall for Dance, the second installment of which runs Tuesday though next Sunday. They complained about unfair competition for audiences and financing, but it's hard to see just what they were upset about, except for all-purpose competitive jealousy. For one thing, dance samplers --
title: DANCE; Too Much! Too Little! Or Maybe Just Right

body: It is not an easy job, towing 150 tons of conceptual art around Manhattan all day. There are tides and wind currents to negotiate. There are ferries and container ships and police boats to avoid. And then there is the precious cargo itself, not exactly your average garbage scow: ''Floating Island,'' designed by the artist Robert Smithson, who died
title: A Miniature Gate in Hot Pursuit of a Miniature Central Park

body: How exactly to approach ''Breaking Ground: A Dance Charrette,'' a 45-minute performance involving five choreographers and a host of dancers that took place twice Saturday afternoon in the handsome old Tobacco Warehouse in Dumbo, with the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges roaring overhead? Site-specific performances with odd ground rules are common
title: DANCE REVIEW; For 5 Artists, an Experiment With Choreography on Deadline

body: Cary McWilliam, a freelance modern dancer and teacher in Manhattan who earns about $23,000 a year, loves the freedom of leaping from one job to the next, unbeholden to any single employer. But that same independence takes a toll on her finances and her nerves. ''With the inconsistent paycheck,'' she said, ''it's hard to save. My retirement is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Highs and Lows of Going It Alone

body: Vito Acconci is cleaning up his act. The 65-year-old renegade artist turned architect has trimmed his mad-scientist's tousled hair so that he looks almost clean-cut. He still wears a uniform of head-to-toe black, but he no longer removes it in public. And he's scaled back the cigarettes, from two-and-a-half packs a day to just one. Perhaps this is
title: The Talk; Space Oddity

body: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: Jacques Torres has introduced Trinitario Treasures chocolate bars, using trinitario cocoa beans from Ghana. He will make the 3.5-ounce bars for the next few months, until his supply of the distinctive small-crop beans runs out. The no-frills semisweet bar, embossed with his signature, is 65 percent cacao and has a fragrance that hints of spice and
title: FOOD STUFF; Sugar and Spice And Prune Hints: How Nice

body: Dates are subject to change. September MIRACLE BROTHERS The toothy Tyler Maynard, who earned rave reviews as Mark, the unambiguously gay boy-band star in ''Altar Boyz,'' gets to show his serious side in this new musical by Kirsten Childs (''The Bubbly Black Girl Sheds Her Chameleon Skin''). An adventure set in 17th-century Brazil, the story follows
title: THE NEW SEASON THEATER; Odd Couples and Naked Girls

body: As much of upper Brooklyn continues to meld into one enormous restaurant row, it can be difficult for established borough restaurants to decide where to open a second location. Dumbo? Williamsburg? Clinton Hill? How about Bushwick or Brownsville? The owners of Tuk Tuk on Smith Street in Cobble Hill, at four years old a neighborhood standby,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; For a Restaurant in the Mainstream, A Cruise Into Uncharted Waters

body: HOW do people do it? Or rather, how do people who have not been given a trust fund or a condo for graduation do it? For people at the bottom of the property ladder, it is sobering to try to enter the real estate market in New York, where the average price of an apartment, $1.3 million, is up 30 percent from the same quarter last year. Even the
title: The Very First Time

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: Prague Kolektiv, a shop specializing in Czech furniture, glassware and lighting from the 1920's and 30's, opened yesterday in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The owners, below, are Barton Quillen (seated), an American, and Giovanni Negrisin, an Italian, who met in Prague about 10 years ago. Both were collecting pieces from what they saw as a pivotal moment in
title: CURRENTS: DESIGN; Relics of Czech Modernism From Between the World Wars

body: THERE are robbers who go for jewels, while others prefer cash. But last month a thief with a taste for culinary excellence stole more than $70,000 worth of appliances from a luxury loft building under construction in Dumbo. As reported in The Brooklyn Paper, the theft occurred at 70 Washington Street, the newest project from David Walentas of Two
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; Haute Heist

body: Dinner With a Dozen A five-course dinner with 12 pinot noir and chardonnay wines from California and Oregon will be served tomorrow at 7 p.m. at Felidia, 243 East 58th Street. The cost is $170; (212)758-1479. Lemonade Toasts Free cookies, milk and lemonade will be served on Saturday from 3 to 6 p.m. at Tate's Bake Shop, 43 North Sea Road,
title: CALENDAR

body: ON the diving board of dashed hopes and denial paces an unhappy figure: the would-be buyer who shops for years but resists taking the plunge. Like timid bathers, some just need time to acclimate to the chilly reality of what their money can't buy. That process can take some time. Eventually, though, after long and careful looking, they do take the
title: Fear of Committing?

body: ON Monday, a sightseeing bus in Times Square was boarded by armed police officers. They herded 60 tourists into the street with their hands in the air, and forced five of them, innocent men it turned out, to kneel in the gutter, with their hands handcuffed behind them. Each of the men was wearing a backpack, which, along with dark complexions (the
title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Zip Search; Accessory to Murder

body: State officials approved a draft plan yesterday for an 85-acre waterfront park near Downtown Brooklyn that would include playing fields, marinas, restaurants and offices, and 1,200 units of luxury housing. The proposed plan for a 1.3-mile shoreline park stretching from the Manhattan Bridge to Cobble Hill is an important step forward in a
title: Agency Adopts Park Plan For Brooklyn Waterfront

body: THE ENEMY OF GOD By Robert Daley Harcourt ($23, hardcover) Frank Redmond was the son of a beer salesman. He grew up on the fourth floor of a walk-up apartment on Marion Avenue in the Bronx, a predominantly Irish Catholic neighborhood not far from the Fordham campus. He played in the streets, which were safe at that time, with kids whose fathers
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/CRIME-THRILLERS; Different Eras, Same Blood and Guts

body: HERE'S an exercise. Google the words ''New Brooklyn'' and see how many hits you come up with. The answer: 15.7 million. Even allowing for the insane inclusiveness of an Internet search, that number reveals something profound about the frenzy -- cultural, gastronomic, architectural and otherwise -- that has seized what is affectionately known as
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; Who Hurts?

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

body: There were 60 scantily clad dancers, and a stage blanketed in glitter and feathers. Lots of feathers. This lavish spectacle was the latest version of the ''Ziegfeld Follies,'' the early-20th-century blockbuster known for its highly synchronized showgirls -- except that this production was very, very small. ''Ziegfeld Minuscule Follies'' had its
title: On Miniature Stages, Performances Crafted From Heart and Paper

title: CALENDAR

body: I DON'T remember the first time I walked into Frank's Gourmet Deli on Smith Street, but it must have been a little more than a year ago, around the time I signed a lease a couple of blocks away in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Getting to know a new neighborhood is always a process of locating and evaluating the essentials -- grocery store, laundry,
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Comfort Food

body: Coal-Fired Flavor Q. The other day, I noticed a coal truck pulling up to a pizza place. Do many pizza places in the city actually use coal ovens? And that reminded me, what about those public schools with coal furnaces that were in the news a few years ago? A. First, the pizzas. There are perhaps a dozen pizzerias in the city that use genuine
title: F.Y.I.

body: FOR those tired of trawling the familiar chain stores, it may be worth making detours to two industrial buildings outside Manhattan where designers and craft specialists work in small studios. One informal collective is in a former factory in Hoboken, N.J., that has eluded gentrification. The other, which includes architects, furniture makers and
title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Artisans, Architects and Furniture Makers, Floor by Floor

The auction of the silver, which includes wine coolers, trays and serving spoons bearing Washington's or the Custis family crest, will be
title: Calendar

body: Susan Woods, 48, is a scavenger trained in painting and sculpture, an artist and designer who works in refuse. She recently combined her own studio and a business that sells the designs of others into a single concern, Aswoon/Susan Woods Studio, and she has just opened a showroom in Dumbo, Brooklyn, that carries two new lines of her furnishings
title: CURRENTS: FURNISHINGS; Fitting Found Objects Into a Landscape of Veils

body: GROWING UP in New Orleans, Bradley Wester used to play with office supplies. Now he's an artist in New York who uses stationery, name tags and stickers for his pop-inspired art, and for the last few months, he has been working out of a small, 350-square foot, light-filled office in lower Manhattan. It is a huge improvement for Mr. Wester, who for
title: SQUARE FEET; For Artists, Cheap Studios in Vacant Commercial Space

body: ''Brooklyn Designs,'' an exhibition of notable Brooklyn-based furnishings designers and manufacturers, begins tomorrow in Dumbo, Brooklyn. A dining armchair (shown in mahogany, top left; $1,500) by Robert Martin (top right; www.robertmartindesigns.com) will be introduced, joining a side chair and dining table in his firm's collection. A Tim
title: CURRENTS: FURNITURE; Young Designers Show Off In Brooklyn

body: THE four-story town house that Darcy Miro and Lars Weiss built on a weedy lot in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, contains no fancy finishes -- no mahogany floors or plaster moldings. On the contrary, there are hardly any finishes at all, barely even drywall, among the exposed joists, electrical conduits and ventilation ducts. These rooms are determinedly
title: Upscale, Downscale

body: ALTHOUGH it has always had a few well-known specialty stores, downtown Manhattan has seemingly overnight become a mecca for food shopping. Trader Joe's is close to signing a lease for space in New York University's new Palladium Complex, a mixed-use development on 14th Street near Third Avenue, according to a retail broker with knowledge of the
title: SQUARE FEET/Downtown Manhattan; A Destination for Serious Eating

body: With all the media coverage beamed in from the Vatican over the past few weeks depicting the late Pope John Paul II as a man of the people, it seems only appropriate that he has received a local sendoff, and in that most democratic of ways: the street mural. Two days after the Pope's death, the graffiti artist James De La Vega painted the first
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; For a Figure on High, Homage From the 'Hood

body: He arrived on foot, and on time, wearing heavily grease-stained beige overalls and boots. He seemed to be in his late 30's or early 40's, with thinning light brown hair. He had the windburned eyes and blackened fingernails of an ironworker, along with the vaguely feral intensity of someone on the lam. But he hardly looked like the kind of shadowy
title: A Graffiti Legend Is Back on the Street

body: She wears hoop earrings and dark spindly eyeglass frames in the latest fashion. She carries a backpack and a digital camera. A young-looking 33 with sandy blond curls, she is a fixture on the streets of East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The hipsters never suspect a thing. She is Dana Ruppert, urban secret agent of sorts, on a mission to document every
title: Nancy Drew and the Hidden Loft; Tracking Illegal Apartments in Industrial Zones

body: Real estate-crazed Americans have started behaving in ways that eerily recall the stock market obsession of the late 1990's. In Naples, Fla., some houses have been bought twice in a single day, an early-21st-century version of day trading. Buying stocks on margin has morphed into buying homes with no money down. The over-the-top parties of Internet
title: Trading Places: Real Estate Instead of Dot-Coms

body: IN the last decade, Williamsburg in Brooklyn has been a first stop for young people new to the city, just out of college. As they have grown up, the neighborhood has too, evolving from dive bars and movie rental joints to chic sushi restaurants and designer furniture emporiums. Most of these Williamsburg devotees are now young professionals, often
title: Williamsburg Reinvented

body: 'El Greco' Islip Art Museum, 50 Irish Lane, East Islip, (631)244-5402. Through April 3. The premise of this show is to compare eight contemporary artists to Domenikos Theotocopoulos, the 16th-century master known as El Greco, because, like him, they supposedly express their ''inner vision'' in opposition to current trends. The artists were selected
title: ART REVIEWS; Getting in Touch With That Inner El Greco

body: Smack-Mellon 56 Water Street Dumbo, Brooklyn Through March 27 This tough-minded theme show doesn't bother much with rhetoric. It just goes straight for pictures, most of them photographs. Few are of actual combat, but almost all document its long-term consequences. The photographer Susan Meiselas, represented by work done in Nicaragua, El Salvador
title: Art in Review; 'On the Subject of War'

title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Colors of Spring Bloom Underfoot

body: THIS is a killer weekend for new art in New York City. Three contemporary fairs -- the Armory Show, Scope New York and the DiVa Digital and Video Art Fair -- are in town for a few cash-crazed days. A show of sculptures called Art Rock is parked in Rockefeller Plaza. And ''Greater New York 2005,'' a survey of some 150 young artists living in and
title: ART; The New Bridge and Tunnel Crowd

body: Three years ago, word spread that Public School 8 in Brooklyn might shut down. Located in a century-old building on Hicks Street, the school serves Dumbo, Vinegar Hill, Fulton Ferry and parts of Brooklyn Heights and Fort Greene. Years of declining enrollment -- largely because neighborhood children were being sent to private schools -- had cast a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; P.S. 8's Comeback Spurs Higher Hopes

title: Spare Times

body: BOLDFACE names, artists and power couples don't always eat where they can be spotted. Sometimes they order in, just like the rest of us. title: Heavenly Fish And Tuna Melt: Notable Names Dine In

Now a virtual theme park of 21st-century commerce housed in 19th- and 20th-century
title: SQUARE FEET/Brooklyn; Working in a Walled-Off Boomtown

body: DEAR Diary: We woke up that Saturday morning giddy over the long-awaited opening of Christo and Jeanne-Claude's ''Gates'' in Central Park. We arrived just in time to see the volunteer workers lining up beneath the last two unfinished gates. As they pulled the ripcords, we, and everyone in the crowd around us, cheered wildly as the final brilliant
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: THE challenge to the developers of Beacon Towers, a high-rise going up just steps from the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn, was apparent one morning last week as Denis R. Milsom, an expert in noise control, strained to be heard above the din of a subway train rumbling over the bridge. ''Clearly, if they want to sell this as a luxury building,'' he
title: TURF; Condos Break Sound Barrier

body: IN a little over two years, Shaya Boymelgreen, an Israeli immigrant who came to New York in 1969 to study at a yeshiva, has gone from being an obscure builder of low-rise apartment houses to become one of the city's busiest residential developers. In partnership with Lev Leviev, an Israeli billionaire and diamond magnate, Mr. Boymelgreen has plans
title: With backing from an Israeli billionaire, a Developer finds opportunity in disparate places

body: WHEN Emily Haddad moved to New York shortly after finishing college in 2001, she didn't know much about the city, but being gay, she knew she wanted to live in a gay-friendly community. Her neighborhood of choice? Park Slope. ''It seemed like lesbian central in New York,'' said Ms. Haddad, 24, whose unaccented speech belies her North Carolina
title: URBAN TACTICS; Replanting The Rainbow Flag

body: Drama is built on character, but a soap opera is rooted in place. A character on ''Days of Our Lives'' or ''General Hospital'' may marry, divorce, be buried alive or lost at sea, but Salem and Port Charles, their famous locales, remain unchanging and eternal. And so not surprisingly, the real stars of ''BrooKenya!,'' a soap opera for which
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Love Triangles, Evil Twins: The International Language

body: For 20 years Mark Russell made a public school in the East Village a center for artists on the fringe, the verge and the cutting edge. P.S. 122 was a paradise of variety and invention. There were monologuists, choreographers, playwrights and puppeteers. The roll call of performers is long and winding: Whoopi Goldberg, Ethyl Eicheberger, Eric
title: The Listings; 'UNDER THE RADAR'
